definition: RecName: Full=Nemertide alpha-8.
title:
TITLE     Peptide ion channel toxins from the bootlace worm, the longest
            animal on Earth
  TITLE     Functional Characterization of the Nemertide alpha Family of
            Peptide Toxins
comment:
[FUNCTION] Highly potent toxin against both insect and some
            mammalian sodium channels (Nav). It potently inhibits inactivation
            of insect sodium channels of B.germanica (BgNav1) and also delays
            the inactivation of mammalian Nav with potent activity on
            Nav1.3/SCN3A and Nav1.4/SCN4A (By similarity). 1 uM is enough to
            completely inhibits the inactivation, resulting in sustained
            non-inactivating currents. In addition, the toxin significantly
            enhances the recovery from inactivation, and the open state is not
            required for the toxin to interact with the channel (By
            similarity). In vivo, injection into brine shrimp (Artemia salina)
            stops movement or causes death after 24 hours (EC(50)=0.4 uM) (By
            similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24,
            ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DQS7}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Confined to the epidermis and to the mucus
            layer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin.
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: does not show effect on rat
            Nav1.8/SCN10A. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:34445875}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the nemertide family. {ECO:0000305}.

definition: RecName: Full=Nemertide alpha-7.
title:
TITLE     Peptide ion channel toxins from the bootlace worm, the longest
            animal on Earth
  TITLE     Functional Characterization of the Nemertide alpha Family of
            Peptide Toxins
comment:
[FUNCTION] Potent toxin against insect sodium channel (Nav) and 5-
            to 100-fold less potent against mammalian sodium channels (By
            similarity). Potently inhibits inactivation of insect sodium
            channels of B.germanica (BgNav1) (EC(50)=9.5 nM) (PubMed:34445875).
            The toxin also delays the inactivation of most mammalian Nav
            (hNav1.1/SCN1A; EC(50)=171.5 nM, rNav1.2/SCN2A; EC(50)=50.4 nM,
            rNav1.3/SCN3A; EC(50)=170.2 nM, rNav1.4/SCN4A; EC(50)=810.6 nM,
            hNav1.5/SCN5A; EC(50)=155.6 nM, mNav1.6/SCN8A; EC(50)=147.6 nM,
            hNav1.9/SCN9A; EC(50)=129 nM) (PubMed:34445875). 1 uM is enough to
            completely inhibits the inactivation, resulting in sustained
            non-inactivating currents (By similarity). In addition, the toxin
            significantly enhances the recovery from inactivation, and the open
            state is not required for the toxin to interact with the channel
            (By similarity). In vivo, injection into brine shrimp (Artemia
            salina) stops movement or causes death after 24 hours (EC(50)=6.1
            uM) (PubMed:34445875). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24,
            ECO:0000269|PubMed:34445875}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Confined to the epidermis and to the mucus
            layer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin.
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: does not show effect on rat
            Nav1.8/SCN10A. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:34445875}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the nemertide family. {ECO:0000305}.

definition: RecName: Full=Nemertide alpha-6.
title:
TITLE     Peptide ion channel toxins from the bootlace worm, the longest
            animal on Earth
  TITLE     Functional Characterization of the Nemertide alpha Family of
            Peptide Toxins
comment:
[FUNCTION] Highly potent toxin against both insect and some
            mammalian sodium channels (Nav) (PubMed:34445875). It potently
            inhibits inactivation of insect sodium channels of B.germanica
            (BgNav1) (EC(50)=2.6 nM) and also delays the inactivation of
            mammalian Nav with potent activity on Nav1.1/SCN1A (hNav1.1/SCN1A;
            EC(50)=7.9 nM, rNav1.2/SCN2A; EC(50)=24.3 nM, rNav1.3/SCN3A;
            EC(50)=105.6 nM, rNav1.4/SCN4A; EC(50)=46.4 nM, hNav1.5/SCN5A;
            EC(50)=215.2 nM, mNav1.6/SCN8A; EC(50)=36.3 nM, hNav1.9/SCN9A;
            EC(50)=97.2 nM) (PubMed:34445875). 1 uM is enough to completely
            inhibits the inactivation, resulting in sustained non-inactivating
            currents (By similarity). In addition, the toxin significantly
            enhances the recovery from inactivation, and the open state is not
            required for the toxin to interact with the channel (By
            similarity). In vivo, injection into brine shrimp (Artemia salina)
            stops movement or causes death after 24 hours (EC(50)=2.8 uM)
            (PubMed:34445875). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24,
            ECO:0000269|PubMed:34445875}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Confined to the epidermis and to the mucus
            layer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin.
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: does not show effect on rat
            Nav1.8/SCN10A. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:34445875}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the nemertide family. {ECO:0000305}.

definition: RecName: Full=Nemertide alpha-5.
title:
TITLE     Peptide ion channel toxins from the bootlace worm, the longest
            animal on Earth
  TITLE     Functional Characterization of the Nemertide alpha Family of
            Peptide Toxins
comment:
[FUNCTION] Highly potent toxin against both insect and some
            mammalian sodium channels (Nav) (PubMed:34445875). It potently
            inhibits inactivation of insect sodium channels of B.germanica
            (BgNav1) (EC(50)=7.8 nM) and also delays the inactivation of
            mammalian Nav with potent activity on Nav1.3/SCN3A and Nav1.4/SCN4A
            (hNav1.1/SCN1A; EC(50)=102.1 nM, rNav1.2/SCN2A; EC(50)=156.1 nM,
            rNav1.3/SCN3A; EC(50)=9.4 nM, rNav1.4/SCN4A; EC(50)=15.4 nM,
            hNav1.5/SCN5A; EC(50)=132.7 nM, mNav1.6/SCN8A; EC(50)=66.9 nM,
            hNav1.9/SCN9A; EC(50)=73 nM) (PubMed:34445875). 1 uM is enough to
            completely inhibits the inactivation, resulting in sustained
            non-inactivating currents (By similarity). In addition, the toxin
            significantly enhances the recovery from inactivation, and the open
            state is not required for the toxin to interact with the channel
            (By similarity). In vivo, injection into brine shrimp (Artemia
            salina) stops movement or causes death after 24 hours (EC(50)=0.4
            uM) (PubMed:34445875). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24,
            ECO:0000269|PubMed:34445875}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Confined to the epidermis and to the mucus
            layer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin.
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: does not show effect on rat
            Nav1.8/SCN10A. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:34445875}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the nemertide family. {ECO:0000305}.

definition: RecName: Full=Nemertide alpha-4.
title:
TITLE     Peptide ion channel toxins from the bootlace worm, the longest
            animal on Earth
  TITLE     Functional Characterization of the Nemertide alpha Family of
            Peptide Toxins
comment:
[FUNCTION] Highly potent toxin against insect sodium channel (Nav)
            and with less potent against some mammalian Nav (PubMed:34445875).
            Potently inhibits inactivation of insect sodium channels of
            B.germanica (BgNav1) (EC(50)=11.1 nM) (PubMed:34445875). Also
            delays the inactivation of most mammalian Nav (hNav1.1/SCN1A;
            EC(50)=92 nM, rNav1.2/SCN2A; EC(50)=134.2 nM, rNav1.3/SCN3A;
            EC(50)=12.9 nM, rNav1.4/SCN4A; EC(50)=14.6 nM, hNav1.5/SCN5A;
            EC(50)=27.8 nM, mNav1.6/SCN8A; EC(50)=123.6 nM, hNav1.9/SCN9A;
            EC(50)=80.5 nM) (PubMed:34445875). 1 uM is enough to completely
            inhibits the inactivation, resulting in sustained non-inactivating
            currents (By similarity). In addition, the toxin significantly
            enhances the recovery from inactivation, and the open state is not
            required for the toxin to interact with the channel (By
            similarity). In vivo, injection into brine shrimp (Artemia salina)
            stops movement or causes death after 24 hours (EC(50)=0.4 uM)
            (PubMed:34445875). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24,
            ECO:0000269|PubMed:34445875}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Confined to the epidermis and to the mucus
            layer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin.
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: does not show effect on rat
            Nav1.8/SCN10A. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:34445875}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the nemertide family. {ECO:0000305}.

definition: RecName: Full=Nemertide alpha-3.
title:
TITLE     Peptide ion channel toxins from the bootlace worm, the longest
            animal on Earth
  TITLE     Functional Characterization of the Nemertide alpha Family of
            Peptide Toxins
comment:
[FUNCTION] Toxin with similar potency against both insect and
            mammalian sodium channels (Nav) (PubMed:34445875). It inhibits
            inactivation of most Nav tested (B.germanica (BgNav1); EC(50)=97.5
            nM, hNav1.1/SCN1A; EC(50)=125.8 nM, rNav1.2/SCN2A; EC(50)=137.8 nM,
            rNav1.3/SCN3A; EC(50)=138.9 nM, rNav1.4/SCN4A; EC(50)=150.2 nM,
            hNav1.5/SCN5A; EC(50)=108.4 nM, mNav1.6/SCN8A; EC(50)=92.8 nM,
            hNav1.9/SCN9A; EC(50)=102.2 nM) (PubMed:34445875). 1 uM is enough
            to completely inhibits the inactivation, resulting in sustained
            non-inactivating currents (By similarity). In addition, the toxin
            significantly enhances the recovery from inactivation, and the open
            state is not required for the toxin to interact with the channel
            (By similarity). In vivo, injection into brine shrimp (Artemia
            salina) stops movement or causes death after 24 hours (EC(50)=4.7
            uM) (PubMed:34445875). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24,
            ECO:0000269|PubMed:34445875}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Confined to the epidermis and to the mucus
            layer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin.
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: does not show effect on rat
            Nav1.8/SCN10A. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:34445875}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the nemertide family. {ECO:0000305}.

title:

            identifies toxin innovation in an Australian tarantula
comment:

            activity when injected into mealworms.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23894279}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin. {ECO:0000250}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 10 (Hwtx-1) family. 46
            (Jztx-7/10/12) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

title:
TITLE     Novel tarantula toxins for subtypes of voltage-dependent potassium
            channels in the Kv2 and Kv4 subfamilies
comment:
[FUNCTION] Acts as a gating-modifier to inhibit voltage-gated
            potassium channels. It inhibits delayed Kv2.1/KCNB1 (IC(50) is 12.7
            nM), Kv2.1/Kv9.3 (IC(50) is 7.2 nM) (KCNB1/KCNS3), Kv2.2/KCNB2
            (IC(50) is 21.4 nM), and transient Kv4.2/KCND2 (IC(50) is 1.2 nM)
            channels. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12065754}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin. {ECO:0000250}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=3788.62; Method=MALDI;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:12065754}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: does not have effect on
            Kv4.1/KCND1 and Kv4.3/KCND3. Intracerebroventricular injection into
            mice does not induce observable neurotoxicity symptoms
            (PubMed:12065754). {ECO:0000305|PubMed:12065754}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 10 (Hwtx-1) family. 57
            (ScTx1) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

definition:
RecName: Full=Omega-theraphotoxin-Hg1a; Short=Omega-TRTX-Hg1a;
AltName: Full=Toxin SNX-482; Short=SNX482.
title:
TITLE     Selective peptide antagonist of the class E calcium channel from
            the venom of the tarantula Hysterocrates gigas
  TITLE     Interaction of SNX482 with domains III and IV inhibits activation
            gating of alpha(1E) (Ca(V)2.3) calcium channels
  TITLE     SNX482 selectively blocks P/Q Ca2+ channels and delays the
            inactivation of Na+ channels of chromaffin cells
comment:
[FUNCTION] Toxin that blocks vertebrate P/Q-type (Cav2.1/CACNA1A)
            and R-type (Cav2.3/CACNA1E) voltage-gated calcium channels. Also
            inhibits sodium channels (Nav) in bovine chromaffin cells by
            delaying sodium channel inactivation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11423396,
            ECO:0000269|PubMed:12954354, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9799496}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin. {ECO:0000250}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 10 (Hwtx-1) family. 56
            (SNX-482) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

definition: RecName: Full=Turripeptide Gsp9.3; Flags: Precursor.
title:
TITLE     Adaptive radiation of venomous marine snail lineages and the
            accelerated evolution of venom peptide genes
comment:
[FUNCTION] Acts as a neurotoxin by inhibiting an ion channel (By
            similarity). May also act as a serine protease inhibitor, since it
            possess the kazal serine protease inhibitor signature.
            {ECO:0000250}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000250}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom duct.
            [DOMAIN] The cysteine framework is IX (C-C-C-C-C-C).
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the conopeptide P-like superfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

definition:
RecName: Full=Kappa-theraphotoxin-Pg1a; Short=Kappa-TRTX-Pg1a;
AltName: Full=Guangxitoxin-1E; Short=GxTx1E.
title:
TITLE     Blockers of the delayed-rectifier potassium current in pancreatic
            beta-cells enhance glucose-dependent insulin secretion
  TITLE     Gating modifier peptides as probes of pancreatic beta-cell
            physiology
  TITLE     A KV2.1 gating modifier binding assay suitable for high throughput
            screening
  TITLE     Solution structure of GxTX-1E, a high-affinity tarantula toxin
            interacting with voltage sensors in Kv2.1 potassium channels
comment:
[FUNCTION] Gating modifier of Kv2.1/KCNB1 (IC(50)=5.1 nM),
            Kv2.2/KCNB2 and Kv4.3/KCND3 channels (IC(50)=39 nM). Acts by
            shifting the channel activation to more depolarized potentials by
            stabilizing the resting conformation of the voltage sensor. It
            completely inhibits opening of the Kv2.1/KCNB1 channel at negative
            membrane voltages and dramatically shifts channel activation to
            positive voltages. May act by partitioning into lipid membranes and
            then by binding the voltage sensor paddle of the channel from a
            place within the membrane. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16567526,
            ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101164, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21150283}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16567526}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16567526}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=3948; Mass_error=0.39; Method=MALDI;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:16567526}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: has no significant effects on
            Kv1.2/KCNA2, Kv1.3/KCNA3, Kv1.5/KCNA5, Kv3.2/KCNC2, Cav1.2/CACNA1C,
            Cav2.2/CACNA1B, Nav1.5/SCN5A, Nav1.7/SCN9A or Nav1.8/SCN10A
            channels.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 10 (Hwtx-1) family. 44
            (Jztx-4) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

definition:
RecName: Full=Mu-theraphotoxin-Hhn1a; Short=Mu-TRTX-Hhn1a; AltName:
Full=Hainantoxin-5; AltName: Full=Hainantoxin-V; Short=HnTX-V.
title:
TITLE     Purification and characterization of Hainantoxin-V, a
            tetrodotoxin-sensitive sodium channel inhibitor from the venom of
            the spider Selenocosmia hainana
comment:
[FUNCTION] Inhibits selectively tetrodotoxin-sensitive
            voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav). Does not act by binding to
            receptor site 3 to slow the inactivation kinetics of sodium
            currents. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12727268}.
            [SUBUNIT] Monomer. {ECO:0000250}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin. {ECO:0000250}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=3972; Method=MALDI;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:12727268}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] IC(50) is 42.3 nM on rat neurons.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 10 (Hwtx-1) family. 22
            (Htx-4) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

definition:
RecName: Full=Psi-conotoxin PIIIE; AltName: Full=Psi-conotoxin
Flags: Precursor.
title:
TITLE     A noncompetitive peptide inhibitor of the nicotinic acetylcholine
            receptor from Conus purpurascens venom
  TITLE     Definition of the M-conotoxin superfamily: characterization of
            novel peptides from molluscivorous Conus venoms
  TITLE     Three-dimensional solution structure of conotoxin psi-PIIIE, an
            acetylcholine gated ion channel antagonist
  TITLE     An improved solution structure for psi-conotoxin PiiiE
comment:
On Jul 11, 2006 this sequence version replaced gi:7227952.
            [FUNCTION] Psi-conotoxins act on postsynaptic membranes, and act as
            non-competitive antagonist of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors
            (nAChR). Is more toxic than Psi-conotoxin PIIIF. In vivo, has
            paralytic activity when injected intraperitoneally into goldfish.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9236004}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9236004}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom duct.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:9236004}.
            [DOMAIN] The cysteine framework is III (CC-C-C-CC). Classified in
            the M-4 branch, since 4 residues stand between the fourth and the
            fifth cysteine residues. {ECO:0000305}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=2716.0; Method=LSI;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:9236004}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the conotoxin M superfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

definition: RecName: Full=Conotoxin Vi6.2; Flags: Precursor.
title: TITLE     Glycine-rich conotoxins from the Virgiconus clade
comment:
[FUNCTION] Ion channel inhibitor that inhibits the increase in
            intracellular calcium upon depolarization in DRG neurons. In vivo,
            both intraperitoneal and intracranial injections into mice induce
            hyperactivity. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q5K0C7}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000305|PubMed:26851775}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom duct.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:26851775}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin. {ECO:0000305}.
            [DOMAIN] The cysteine framework is VI/VII (C-C-CC-C-C).
            {ECO:0000305}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the conotoxin O1 superfamily.
            {ECO:0000305}.

definition:
RecName: Full=Toxin Bcg III 23.41; Short=Bcg 23.41; AltName:
Full=AnmTX BC 9a-1.
title:
TITLE     Proteomics of the neurotoxic fraction from the sea anemone
            Bunodosoma cangicum venom: novel peptides belonging to new classes
            of toxins
  TITLE     Sea anemone peptide with uncommon beta-hairpin structure inhibits
            acid-sensing ion channel 3 (ASIC3) and reveals analgesic activity
comment:
[FUNCTION] Possible voltage-gated potassium channel (Kv) blocker.
            Increases amplitude and duration of crab leg nerve compound action
            potential. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20483220}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000305}. Nematocyst
            {ECO:0000305}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=3176.36; Method=MALDI;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:20483220}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the sea anemone structural class 9a family.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:23801332}.

definition: RecName: Full=Nemertide alpha-2.
title:
TITLE     Peptide ion channel toxins from the bootlace worm, the longest
            animal on Earth
  TITLE     Functional Characterization of the Nemertide alpha Family of
            Peptide Toxins
comment:
[FUNCTION] Toxin with similar potency against both insect and
            mammalian sodium channels (Nav) (PubMed:34445875). Delays the
            inactivation of most Nav channels tested (B.germanica (BgNav1);
            EC(50)=87.2 nM, hNav1.1/SCN1A; EC(50)=125.8 nM, rNav1.2/SCN2A;
            EC(50)=97.9 nM, rNav1.3/SCN3A; EC(50)=127.7 nM, rNav1.4/SCN4A;
            EC(50)=1150.3 nM, hNav1.5/SCN5A; EC(50)=149.2 nM, mNav1.6/SCN8A;
            EC(50)=1361.8 nM, hNav1.9/SCN9A; EC(50)=1296.7 nM)
            (PubMed:34445875). 1 uM is enough to completely inhibits the
            inactivation, resulting in sustained non-inactivating currents (By
            similarity). In addition, the toxin significantly enhances the
            recovery from inactivation, and the open state is not required for
            the toxin to interact with the channel (By similarity). In vivo,
            injection into brine shrimp (Artemia salina) stops movement or
            causes death after 24 hours (EC(50)=2.9 uM) (PubMed:34445875).
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0DM24, ECO:0000269|PubMed:34445875}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000305|PubMed:29567943}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Confined to the epidermis and to the mucus
            layer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:29567943}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:29567943}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=3260.738; Method=MALDI;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:29567943}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negative results: does not show effect on rat
            Nav1.8/SCN10A. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:34445875}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the nemertide family. {ECO:0000305}.

definition:
RecName: Full=Kappa-theraphotoxin-Tb1c; Short=Kappa-TRTX-Tb1c;
AltName: Full=Theraphotoxin-3; AltName: Full=TlTx3.
title:
TITLE     Nanospray analysis of the venom of the tarantula Theraphosa
            leblondi: a powerful method for direct venom mass fingerprinting
            and toxin sequencing
  TITLE     Modulation of Kv4.2 channels by a peptide isolated from the venom
            of the giant bird-eating tarantula Theraphosa leblondi
comment:
[FUNCTION] Blocks Kv4.2/KCND2 voltage-gated potassium channels
            probably by shifting the voltage-dependence of channel activation
            to more depolarized potentials and by binding to the S3-S4 linker
            region of the voltage sensor domain. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15150824}.
            [SUBUNIT] Monomer. {ECO:0000305}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15150824,
            ECO:0000269|PubMed:15208026}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:15150824, ECO:0000305|PubMed:15208026}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin.
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P58426}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=4208.78; Method=Electrospray;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:15150824}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=4205.88; Method=MALDI; Note=Monoisotopic
            mass.; Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:15208026}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 10 (Hwtx-1) family. 59
            (Tltx) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

definition:
RecName: Full=Kappa-theraphotoxin-Tb1b; Short=Kappa-TRTX-Tb1b;
AltName: Full=Theraphotoxin-2; AltName: Full=TlTx2.
title:
TITLE     Nanospray analysis of the venom of the tarantula Theraphosa
            leblondi: a powerful method for direct venom mass fingerprinting
            and toxin sequencing
  TITLE     Modulation of Kv4.2 channels by a peptide isolated from the venom
            of the giant bird-eating tarantula Theraphosa leblondi
comment:
[FUNCTION] Low-affinity blocker of Kv4.2/KCND2 voltage-gated
            potassium channels. Is presumed to shift the voltage-dependence of
            channel activation to more depolarized potentials and to bind to
            the S3-S4 linker region of the voltage sensor domain.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15150824, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15208026}.
            [SUBUNIT] Monomer. {ECO:0000305}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000305}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland. {ECO:0000305}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin. {ECO:0000250}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=4195.56; Method=Electrospray;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:15150824}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=4192.90; Method=MALDI; Note=Monoisotopic
            mass.; Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:15208026}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 10 (Hwtx-1) family. 58
            subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

definition:
RecName: Full=Kappa-theraphotoxin-Tb1a; Short=Kappa-TRTX-Tb1a;
AltName: Full=Theraphotoxin-1; AltName: Full=TlTx1.
title:
TITLE     Nanospray analysis of the venom of the tarantula Theraphosa
            leblondi: a powerful method for direct venom mass fingerprinting
            and toxin sequencing
  TITLE     Modulation of Kv4.2 channels by a peptide isolated from the venom
            of the giant bird-eating tarantula Theraphosa leblondi
comment:
[FUNCTION] Blocks Kv4.2/KCND2 voltage-gated potassium channels
            (IC(50) is 193.0 nM) by shifting the voltage-dependence of channel
            activation to more depolarized potentials. The toxin is thought to
            bind to the S3-S4 linker region of the voltage sensor domain.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15150824, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15208026}.
            [SUBUNIT] Monomer. {ECO:0000305}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000305}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland. {ECO:0000305}.

            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=4186.33; Method=Electrospray;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:15150824}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=4183.8; Method=MALDI; Note=Monoisotopic
            mass.; Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:15208026}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 10 (Hwtx-1) family. 59
            (Tltx) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

definition:
RecName: Full=Mu-theraphotoxin-Hhn1d; Short=Mu-TRTX-Hhn1d; AltName:
Full=Hainantoxin-IV-3; Short=HNTX-IV-3; Flags: Precursor.
title:
TITLE     Molecular diversification of peptide toxins from the tarantula
            Haplopelma hainanum (Ornithoctonus hainana) venom based on
            transcriptomic, peptidomic, and genomic analyses
comment:
[FUNCTION] Neurotoxin. Selectively blocks neuronal
            tetrodotoxin-sensitive voltage-gated sodium channels (Nav). Does
            not affect tetrodotoxin-resistant voltage-gated sodium channels or
            calcium channels. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:D2Y232}.
            [SUBUNIT] Monomer. {ECO:0000250}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000250}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin. {ECO:0000250}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 10 (Hwtx-1) family. 22
            (Htx-4) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:23801332}.

definition: RecName: Full=Neurotoxin PRTx26An0C3.
title:
TITLE     Comparison of the partial proteomes of the venoms of Brazilian
            spiders of the genus Phoneutria
  TITLE     A new family of small (4kDa) neurotoxins from the venoms of spiders
            of the genus Phoneutria
comment:
[FUNCTION] Neurotoxin. Causes spastic paralysis and death in mice.
            Moderate inhibitor of L-type calcium channels (Cav1/CACNA1).
            {ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16278100,
            ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16278100, ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin.
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P31328}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=4058.07; Mass_error=0.45;
            Method=Electrospray; Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:16278100,
            ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=4058.7; Method=Unknown;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:16278100, ECO:0000269|Ref.2}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 10 (Hwtx-1) family. 53
            (PNTx27C4) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

definition:
RecName: Full=Conotoxin SIVC; AltName: Full=KappaA-conotoxin SIVC;
AltName: Full=STR18.
title:
TITLE     Venom duct origins of prey capture and defensive conotoxins in
            piscivorous Conus striatus
  TITLE     Proteomic Analysis of the Predatory Venom of Conus striatus Reveals
            Novel and Population-Specific kappaA-Conotoxin SIVC
comment:
[FUNCTION] Probable neurotoxin with ion channel inhibitor activity.
            {ECO:0000305}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:36422973}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom duct. Low expression in
            the distal venom duct sections. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:34168165}.
            [DOMAIN] The cysteine framework is IV (CC-C-C-C-C). {ECO:0000305}.
            [PTM] O-linked glycans consist of Hex4-HexNAc2 hexasaccharides.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:36422973}.
            [PTM] N-terminus is found to be free and N-acetylated, depending on
            the fraction studied. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:36422973}.
            [PTM] Contains 3 disulfide bonds. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:36422973}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the conotoxin A superfamily.
            {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0C1X1, ECO:0000305|PubMed:34168165}.
            [CAUTION] Found in the venom of the population of Pionoconus
            striatus from Mayotte island, but not detected in the venom of
            Australian cones. Nevertheless, it is weakly detected at the
            transcriptomic level in Australian cones.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:34168165, ECO:0000269|PubMed:36422973}.
            [WEB RESOURCE] Name=National Center for Biotechnology Information
            (NCBI); URL='https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/bioproject/PRJNA730990'.

Short=KappaA-PIVF.
title:
TITLE     Discovery and characterization of the short kappaA-conotoxins: a
            novel subfamily of excitatory conotoxins
comment:
[FUNCTION] Probable neurotoxin with ion channel inhibitor activity
            (Probable). In vivo, elicits dose-dependently excitatory activity
            upon injection into fish. Its action is slowly reversible (By
            similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P0C2C5, ECO:0000305}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17118419}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom duct.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:17118419}.
            [DOMAIN] The cysteine framework is IV (CC-C-C-C-C). {ECO:0000305}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the conotoxin A superfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

definition:
RecName: Full=Conotoxin PIVE; AltName: Full=Kappa-A-conotoxin PIVE;
Short=KappaA-PIVE.
title:
TITLE     Discovery and characterization of the short kappaA-conotoxins: a
            novel subfamily of excitatory conotoxins
comment:
[FUNCTION] Probable neurotoxin with ion channel inhibitor activity
            (Probable). In vivo, elicits dose-dependently excitatory activity
            upon injection into fish. Its action is slowly reversible
            (PubMed:17118419). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17118419, ECO:0000305}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17118419}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom duct.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:17118419}.
            [DOMAIN] The cysteine framework is IV (CC-C-C-C-C). {ECO:0000305}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=2656; Method=LSI;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:17118419}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] Negatives results: does not have any direct effects
            on neuromuscular nAChRs (human adult alpha-1/beta-1/epsilon/delta
            or fetal alpha-1/beta-1/gamma/delta receptors). Does not have any
            effects on human Kv1 (KCNA1, KCNA2, KCNA3, KCNA4, KCNA5, and KCNA),
            Kv2.1/KCNB1, Kv3.4 (KCNC4), Kv4.2 (KCND2), KCNQ2/3, and on the
            Drosophilia Shaker potassium channels. Does not have effects on the
            fish potassium channels, TSha1, TSha2 (Kv1 homologs), and Traw (Kv3
            homolog). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17118419}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the conotoxin A superfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

definition: RecName: Full=27 kDa antibacterial protein.
title:
TITLE     Characterization and ion channel activities of novel antibacterial
            proteins from the skin mucosa of carp (Cyprinus carpio)
comment:
On Jun 21, 2005 this sequence version replaced gi:7512124.
            [FUNCTION] Has antibacterial activity. It inhibits fish bacterial
            pathogens, A.hydrophila and M.luteus, and also E.coli,
            P.fluorescens and S.aureus. Forms large ion channels responsible
            for disrupting the cellular envelope of bacteria leading to cell
            lysis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8797847, ECO:0000305}.
            [PTM] Glycosylated. {ECO:0000305}.

definition:
RecName: Full=U1-theraphotoxin-Tal1a; Short=U1-TRTX-Tal1a; AltName:
Full=Brachyin; Flags: Precursor.
title:
TITLE     A novel neurotoxin from venom of the spider, Brachypelma
            albopilosum
comment:
[FUNCTION] Insecticidal toxin that shows strong lethal effects on
            American cockroaches (P.americana) and common mealbeetle
            (T.molitor) (PubMed:25329070). Possibly acts by blocking ion
            channel currents (Probable). Also shows significant analgesic
            effects in mice models of pain including abdominal writhing induced
            by acetic acid and formalin-induced paw licking tests
            (PubMed:25329070). In addition, exerts marked inhibition of
            proliferation of some human tumor cell lines including C8166,
            Molt-4, A-549, BIU-87, T24, and Calu-6 (PubMed:25329070).
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25329070, ECO:0000305}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25329070}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:25329070}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin. {ECO:0000305}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=4901.7; Method=MALDI;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:25329070}.
            [TOXIC DOSE] LD(50) is 5 ug/kg in adult cockroaches.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25329070}.
            [TOXIC DOSE] LD(50) is 7.6 ug/kg in mealbeetles.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25329070}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 14 (magi-1) family. 08
            (Ltx-4) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

title:
TITLE     SVM-based prediction of propeptide cleavage sites in spider toxins
            identifies toxin innovation in an Australian tarantula

definition:
RecName: Full=Delta-amaurobitoxin-Pl1a; Short=Delta-AMATX-Pl1a;
AltName: Full=Delta-palutoxin IT1; Short=Delta-paluIT1.
title:
TITLE     Isolation, synthesis and pharmacological characterization of
            delta-palutoxins IT, novel insecticidal toxins from the spider
            Paracoelotes luctuosus (Amaurobiidae)
  TITLE     A recombinant fusion protein containing a spider toxin specific for
            the insect voltage-gated sodium ion channel shows oral toxicity
            towards insects of different orders
  TITLE     Solution structure of two insect-specific spider toxins and their
            pharmacological interaction with the insect voltage-gated Na+
            channel
comment:
On Jun 10, 2005 this sequence version replaced gi:25294215.
            [FUNCTION] Binds at site 4 of sodium channels (Nav) and inhibits
            the fast inactivation of cockroach channels. This toxin is active
            only on insects. Has a potent activity against S.litura larvae.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10971590}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10971590}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom gland.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10971590}.
            [DOMAIN] The presence of a 'disulfide through disulfide knot'
            structurally defines this protein as a knottin. {ECO:0000305}.
            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=4037.9; Method=MALDI;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:10971590}.
            [BIOTECHNOLOGY] Could be considered as a biological insecticide
            candidate, when fused to Galanthus nivalis agglutinin (GNA), a
            protein with the potential to cross the insect gut. This chimeric
            Pl1a/GNA variant shows a gain in toxicity against insects when
            administered orally, while maintaining similar effects as the
            wild-type toxin when injected. Transport of Pl1a/GNA variant from
            gut contents to the hemolymph of cabbage moth larvae, and binding
            to the nerve chord, has been shown. This variant has been found to
            be orally toxic against cabbage moth (Mamestra brassicae), housefly
            (Musca domestica), and the hemipteran Acyrthosiphon pisum.
            {ECO:0000305|PubMed:24486516}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 07 (Beta/delta-agtx) family.
            02 (aga-3) subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

            [MISCELLANEOUS] Blockers of Kv2.1/KCNB1 potassium channels may be a
            useful approach to the design of novel therapeutic agents for the

            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the neurotoxin 10 (Hwtx-1) family. 44

title:

            selective L-type calcium ion channel blocker isolated from the
            venom of Conus marmoreus
  TITLE     The metal-free and calcium-bound structures of a
            gamma-carboxyglutamic acid-containing contryphan from Conus
            marmoreus, glacontryphan-M
comment:
[FUNCTION] Inhibits high (L-type) voltage-activated calcium
            channels (Cav) in a calcium-dependent manner.
            {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15155730}.
            [SUBCELLULAR LOCATION] Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15155730}.
            [TISSUE SPECIFICITY] Expressed by the venom duct.

            [MASS SPECTROMETRY] Mass=1471.47; Method=Electrospray;
            Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:15155730}.
            [MISCELLANEOUS] In contrast to the other contryphans,
            glacontryphan-M is a single homogenous conformer exhibiting no cis
            to trans isomerization of the Cys-Pro peptidyl bond in aqueous
            solution. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15155731}.
            [SIMILARITY] Belongs to the O2 superfamily. Contryphan family.
            {ECO:0000305}.
